content.statement: aku-001-fibonacci-sequence-definition is a fundamental concept in Science Math Number-Theory Fibonacci that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku-001-fibonacci-sequence-definition helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku-001-fibonacci-sequence-definition include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku-001-fibonacci-sequence-definition.

definitions_glossary.recurrence_relation: An equation that defines a sequence where each term is a function of preceding terms
definitions_glossary.golden_ratio: φ = (1+√5)/2 ≈ 1.618, the limit of ratios of consecutive Fibonacci numbers
definitions_glossary.fibonacci_prime: A Fibonacci number that is also prime (e.g., 2, 3, 5, 13, 89)
definitions_glossary.lucas_numbers: A related sequence: L₀=2, L₁=1, Lₙ=Lₙ₋₁+Lₙ₋₂
definitions_glossary.binets_formula: Closed-form expression for the nth Fibonacci number

properties: Fₙ₊₁ / Fₙ → φ (golden ratio) as n → ∞
Every third Fibonacci number is even (divisible by 2)
Every fourth Fibonacci number is divisible by 3
Sum of first n Fibonacci numbers: ΣFᵢ = Fₙ₊₂ - 1

binets_formula.note: Remarkable that this irrational formula always yields integers

definition.@value: A sequence where each term equals the sum of the two preceding terms, starting with 0 and 1

prerequisites.title: Addition
prerequisites.reason: Fibonacci numbers defined by adding previous terms

prerequisites.title: Sequences
prerequisites.reason: Fibonacci is a fundamental example of recursive sequences

enables.title: Golden Ratio
enables.reason: Fibonacci ratios converge to golden ratio

enables.title: Phyllotaxis (Plant Patterns)
enables.reason: Fibonacci numbers appear in plant spiral patterns

related.relationship: Lucas numbers follow same recurrence with different initial values
Some Fibonacci numbers are prime (Fibonacci primes)

skos:related.skos:note: Limit of consecutive Fibonacci number ratios
Fibonacci primes are intersection of both concepts

learning_objectives: Define the Fibonacci sequence and recurrence relation
Appreciate both recursive and closed-form representations
common_errors: Starting with F₁=1, F₂=1 instead of F₀=0, F₁=1
Thinking the pattern is multiplication, not addition
teaching_tips: Start with the rabbit population problem from Liber Abaci
Show visual patterns: spirals in nature (sunflowers, pinecones, shells)
Connect to golden ratio through consecutive ratios
Use hands-on activities: counting petals, seeds, spirals
Demonstrate both recursive and iterative computation
Show Binet's formula as a beautiful surprise
pedagogical.historical_context: Leonardo Fibonacci introduced the sequence in 1202 in his book Liber Abaci (Book of Calculation) through a problem about rabbit population growth. The sequence was actually known to Indian mathematicians centuries earlier, but Fibonacci popularized it in Europe.
